div.l: And nyste where she was for it was derk
But fayr and wel she crepte vnto the clerk
And lith ful still ⁊and wold haue caught a sleep
Wyth ynne a whyle thys Iohn vp leep
And on thys good wyf he leyeth on sore
So mery a fytte ne hadde not she ful yore
He prykyd hard and sore as he were mad
Thys Ioly lyf haue thyse two clerkis lad
Tyl that the thrydde cok began to synge
Aleyn wext wery in the dawnynge
For he had swonken al the longe nyght
And sayd fare wel malyn swete wyght
The day is come I may no lenger byde
Yet euermore where so y go or ryde
I am thyn owen clerk so haue I hele
Now dere lemman quod she go fare wele
But or thou go o thyng I wol the telle
When þᵗat thou wendyst homward by the melle
Ryght atte entre of the dore behynde
Thou shalt a cake of half abusshel fynde
That was maad of thyn owen mele
Whych that I halp my syre forto stele
And gode lemman god the saue ⁊and kepe
And with that word almost she gan to wepe
Aleyn vprist and thoughte or that it dawe
I wyl go crepe in by my felawe
And fond the cradyl wyth hys hond anon
Be god thoughte he al wrong haue I gon
My hed is toty of my swynk to nyght
That makyth me that I go not a right
I wote wel by the cradyl I haue mys go
Here lith the myllere and hys wyf also
And forth he goth a twenty deuyl way
In to the bed there the myllere lay
He wende haue cropen in by hys felow Iohn
And by the myller in he crepe anon
And caughte hym by the necke ⁊and softe spak
He sayd thou Iohn thou swyneshede awake
